results.content: I never knew there was so much you could do with the chrome developer tools. I recently made a wordpress website and it was running really slow. Within the first few lessons I figured out how to look at my site and was able to figure out what plug-in was slowing it down.  The pace is nice, not to fast, not to slow, glad the instructor didn't explain what css or html is again, as so many tutorials do.

results.content: Informative class, but it moves pretty quick.  If you're new to the game like I am you may wish that things moved a bit slower and went a little deeper.  I've heard from some people that this is a great course if you already have your feet underneath you and are looking to build upon your skills.

I've heard from some people that this is a great course if you already have your feet underneath you and are looking to build upon your skills.

results.content:
Rocco did a very good job of introducing and offering examples of working Chrome DevTools to inspect your web development or other web sites. I have almost exclusively been working with FireBug in Firefox and wanted to become more intimate with Chrome's debugger. The pace was fine, the examples were good and the additional pointers with other software items such as TodoMVC - local host, Lighthouse and NGrok made me more aware of other resources.
My favorite new skills were:
* workspace
* code snippets
* detecting memory leaks

response.content: I love snippets. I think they're called scratchpad or something like that in firefox. Thanks for your feedback! Glad you enjoyed the course.
response.content_html: I love snippets. I think they're called scratchpad or something like that in firefox. Thanks for your feedback! Glad you enjoyed the course.

results.content_html:
Rocco did a very good job of introducing and offering examples of working Chrome DevTools to inspect your web development or other web sites. I have almost exclusively been working with FireBug in Firefox and wanted to become more intimate with Chrome's debugger. The pace was fine, the examples were good and the additional pointers with other software items such as TodoMVC - local host, Lighthouse and NGrok made me more aware of other resources.
My favorite new skills were:
* workspace
* code snippets
* detecting memory leaks

results.content:
The instructor has a very clear and pleasant inviting voice - this is very important for video learning.  Rocco did a great job and I really liked this course especially how to do JS snippets which I did not know how to do prior to this.  I also did search for resources on DevTools and not much out there which is too bad as this is such a feature rich tool and really helps to better understand how it all works.  

Top notch stuff - highly recommended.

results.content: It has ton of information. We are aware with dev tools but through this course i was able to learn correct way of using them and also taught me some really cool features of dev tool :)
results.content_html: It has ton of information. We are aware with dev tools but through this course i was able to learn correct way of using them and also taught me some really cool features of dev tool :)

results.content: The course is good with a lot of useful information. It was a bit fast sometimes with unexplained bits which makes a few things hard to understand for people with non-IT background. As an example, In a few areas where coding was involved was a bit fast and difficult to catch for someone with no coding experience, for example debugging node.js...what were those commands for? One may say...It is not a coding course, Yes sure! BUT a little introduction (few sentences) whenever a new tool or new application or new website is mentioned gives one context and then proceeding to debugging would help. Overall, the course is informative, Thank you.

results.content:
This course is for beginners, there are definitely some take away from this course.
I feel few chapters are just rushed with in 2/3 mins those could have been better. again if you are looking to learn from advance debugging tip and tricks this course is not for you but if you are new to chrome devtools this course is for you.

results.content: The class has very useful information but it feels scattered at the beginning. It gets better as it goes in more detail in the second half of the tutorial.

results.content: Videos keep blurring and refocusing every 5 seconds. Super annoying. Overall course covers only the basics so might be good if you're new to web-dev but nothing fancy here.

response.content:
Hi! Thanks for your thoughts!

I've uploaded my videos in HD quality to Udemy, and there's not too much I can do to improve that. Have you tried other courses to see if there's an issue with your internet connection? This article might help: https://support.udemy.com/hc/en-us/articles/229231227-Video-Playback-Issues

I do see that you progressed all the way through the course. Sorry that it didn't meet your expectations with regards to depth. While I didn't take a deep dive into every topic Chrome Developer Tools related, I did cover a lot of things that professional web developers in my office did not know. 

I'll see what I can do to improve the depth of the course. Feel free to send me a message if there's something that you would have liked to have seen in more detail. Maybe there's an opportunity for me to do an advanced course.
response.content_html:
Hi! Thanks for your thoughts!

I've uploaded my videos in HD quality to Udemy, and there's not too much I can do to improve that. Have you tried other courses to see if there's an issue with your internet connection? This article might help: https://support.udemy.com/hc/en-us/articles/229231227-Video-Playback-Issues

I do see that you progressed all the way through the course. Sorry that it didn't meet your expectations with regards to depth. While I didn't take a deep dive into every topic Chrome Developer Tools related, I did cover a lot of things that professional web developers in my office did not know.

I'll see what I can do to improve the depth of the course. Feel free to send me a message if there's something that you would have liked to have seen in more detail. Maybe there's an opportunity for me to do an advanced course.

results.content_html: Videos keep blurring and refocusing every 5 seconds. Super annoying. Overall course covers only the basics so might be good if you're new to web-dev but nothing fancy here.

results.content: That was a good course. I'm not an experienced developer but I have worked with devtools for a while. I hoped to find out about interesting features I haven't used before. Although it was a good overview of the main features developers use in their everyday development routine, I was aware of most of these things. I'd like to have a more detailed overview of different features (in "More tools" we have a lot of options but only few of them were described in this course). I really liked the section about client-side performance monitoring and having more rarely used features here would be awesome.
results.content_html: That was a good course. I'm not an experienced developer but I have worked with devtools for a while. I hoped to find out about interesting features I haven't used before. Although it was a good overview of the main features developers use in their everyday development routine, I was aware of most of these things. I'd like to have a more detailed overview of different features (in "More tools" we have a lot of options but only few of them were described in this course). I really liked the section about client-side performance monitoring and having more rarely used features here would be awesome.

results.content: Very thorough course. Moves through the tips faster towards the end so I'll need to go back and re-watch some of them to really grock the sequence of steps, but they are very useful & practical. They probably just seem rapid fire because I've not seen them before. I'd rather have more tips even if they are shown faster then fewer tips shown slower any day.

results.content: I  have a chrome book. I also have a mac and Ubuntu  computer. I have also in the past used virtual box for windows 10. I also studied C programming from Udemey so I get the info about programs sucking up memory. I took this course wanting to learn more about using the chrome command prompt. I didn't get that information but I appreciate the info about macs and using chrome to better sync my chrome book through google drive. I would like to know if  you  plan to make a course on the chrome book command line in the future though.....
results.content_html: I have a chrome book. I also have a mac and Ubuntu computer. I have also in the past used virtual box for windows 10. I also studied C programming from Udemey so I get the info about programs sucking up memory. I took this course wanting to learn more about using the chrome command prompt. I didn't get that information but I appreciate the info about macs and using chrome to better sync my chrome book through google drive. I would like to know if you plan to make a course on the chrome book command line in the future though.....

results.content: Great course that delivers what it sets out to - you will have a thorough grasp of what the DevTools can do for you. The course itself could use a little polish in production values and it sometimes feels like things weren't planned or rehearsed or are glossed over - but only when the feature being discussed is very specialized or rarely used. Still, an excellent way to learn the Chrome Dev Tools and your time and money will be well spent.

results.content: Over promised and under delivered. I did learn a couple tips but this is more of an intro to Chrome DevTools and only touches on a bunch of stuff that it can do. It won't allow you to "Building Beautiful, Fast, and Bug Free Web Applications with Google Chrome DevTools" or make you an expert.  I also found the asking for a review  6-7 times in a 2.5 hr course really annoying.
results.content_html: Over promised and under delivered. I did learn a couple tips but this is more of an intro to Chrome DevTools and only touches on a bunch of stuff that it can do. It won't allow you to "Building Beautiful, Fast, and Bug Free Web Applications with Google Chrome DevTools" or make you an expert. I also found the asking for a review 6-7 times in a 2.5 hr course really annoying.

results.content:
There's alot of good basic stuff in this tutorial.
The parts that i was mostly interested in sadly got passed over fairly quick (the whole profiler, reading and understanding the performance/profiler output)
I was missing a quick explantion of what the js heap / nodes / documents was during the memory explanation.

I was also hoping there would be a more thorough explanation of the performance profiler timeline in general.
Firstpaint, first contentfull paint.
frames, and the breakdown of pageload functions and their responsetimes in the timeline.

I've used the devtools since i started in school, but still learned a couple things from this course. So overall i'm happy :) thank you!

results.content:
This course needs to be polished on the aspect of aesthetics.
Sound is not consistent in volume and quality.
Video is fast forward and paused or cut off abruptly.
The author touches subject he knows little about and is honest about it, but for
me it was annoying because I did wanted to know more about that subject.
Also if somebody is doubtful about his knowledge it makes you question if all other things he said is correct.
I did however pick up some thing I did not know :)

response.content:
Howdy, thanks for your feedback! There are definitely some rough spots with the audio, which I will improve upon with the next version of the course. I do have a pretty solid understanding of the developer tools. I think you might be referring to the lecture about Workspaces 2.0, with regards to something I admitted I didn't know. These are a fairly new feature in DevTools and don't work properly with every website set up.

Anyway, sorry this one didn't live up to your expectations. Udemy has a refund policy if you're not completely satisfied. Cheers.
response.content_html:
Howdy, thanks for your feedback! There are definitely some rough spots with the audio, which I will improve upon with the next version of the course. I do have a pretty solid understanding of the developer tools. I think you might be referring to the lecture about Workspaces 2.0, with regards to something I admitted I didn't know. Anyway, sorry this one didn't live up to your expectations. Udemy has a refund policy if you're not completely satisfied. Cheers.

response.content:
Thanks for your review.

Yep, workspaces were tricky, and I admit that I do not use them at work because they are difficult to set up with different mappings. This animation might help make it a bit more clear https://umaar.com/dev-tips/123-workspaces-2-0/. 

Umaar also has a devtools course at that site (that came out a month or two after mine). He's a sharp guy. I'll be taking his course in the future to see if there's any additional knowledge I can share about workspaces 2.0.
response.content_html:
Thanks for your review.

Yep, workspaces were tricky, and I admit that I do not use them at work because they are difficult to set up with different mappings. This animation might help make it a bit more clear https://umaar.com/dev-tips/123-workspaces-2-0/.

Umaar also has a devtools course at that site (that came out a month or two after mine). He's a sharp guy. I'll be taking his course in the future to see if there's any additional knowledge I can share about workspaces 2.0.

results.content:
I've only just begun this course, so this is early for me to write a review.  However I am impressed by what I have seen so far.  The instructor presents the subject matter clearly and expertly.
  If you do any web development at all, this course is a very useful item to add to your tool bag.  I have already learned things that will help me to be more efficient when working on my websites.  It is so much easier having an excellent guide like Rocco Balsamo show you the ropes on something like this instead of wading through all of the documentation yourself even if you knew where to look.  
I highly recommend this course for anyone who would like to be more adept at using Google Chrome Development Tools.  This is one course I'm glad I signed up for.

response.content: Thanks for your glowing review. I am glad you are enjoying the course and hope that you stick with it.

results.content: I am 20 minutes in and was asked to review this course by Udemy. While I don't feel like I've seen enough of this course yet to be completely objective in my thoughts about this course, I do think the instructor does *not* go into enough detail when talking about the different dev tabs and why you would use them. For example, the instructor says things like: "This does this" but doesn't say WHY you would ever do that (a good example is the loop with i and Hello when talking about the console tab...what's the point of writing code in the console like that?...so far I am definitely not impressed and feeling like I just wasted 20 bucks on this course. Not seeing much instruction that I couldn't get with a simple Google search. I see no added value for me as a developer in watching this course so far. I hope it gets better and he doesn't just do things with no background information on the why's and hows.
results.content_html: I am 20 minutes in and was asked to review this course by Udemy. While I don't feel like I've seen enough of this course yet to be completely objective in my thoughts about this course, I do think the instructor does *not* go into enough detail when talking about the different dev tabs and why you would use them. For example, the instructor says things like: "This does this" but doesn't say WHY you would ever do that (a good example is the loop with i and Hello when talking about the console tab...what's the point of writing code in the console like that?...so far I am definitely not impressed and feeling like I just wasted 20 bucks on this course. results.content: excellent survey of the tools - presentation is done pretty well, the emphasis being step-by-step - I gave the course a rating of 4 rather than 5 because I had hoped for a clearer theme and more organization - seemed like the organization was a bit haphazard, ie. "if you want to check {name the topic}, then you go to devtools and click {name the tab} then you do this and that to get results" - I think the scope of the course was too narrowly framed, and thus too short - nice would be a systematic set of web development problems where devtools are applied to identify the causes and integrating devtools into a web dev's workflow.

response.content: Thanks for the review! I'll definitely integrate your feedback into the next version of the course. I wrote a little bit about the course creation process here, if you want to check it out! And yes, even myself I thought I could have done a better job of making a consistent theme through the course: https://hackernoon.com/the-online-tech-teaching-hustle-w-udemy-bdad05e49d02

results.content:
I've been professionally developing for a year but I found dev tools to be crowded and hard to use. Plus, I knew they were powerful but I didn't get how VERY powerful. 

Learning about the 6 different kinds of breakpoints, how to quickly insert a console.log without going to the code, how to step BACK UP the stack, and how to track memory leaks has made me a hard-core dev tools addict. 

Dev tools have been updated past this course a little, but as of mid-2018 I still got everything I needed out of this course. Thank you!
results.content_html:
I've been professionally developing for a year but I found dev tools to be crowded and hard to use. Plus, I knew they were powerful but I didn't get how VERY powerful.

Learning about the 6 different kinds of breakpoints, how to quickly insert a console.log without going to the code, how to step BACK UP the stack, and how to track memory leaks has made me a hard-core dev tools addict.

Dev tools have been updated past this course a little, but as of mid-2018 I still got everything I needed out of this course. Thank you!

results.content: My first udemy course, but I enjoyed it thoroughly. I have some prior experience with chrome dev tools, but there were still some tips I will be taking with me from this course. If I were to nitpick, the instructor gave detailed info on how to setup the various tools needed for the course. I only wish there was a video on setting up the specific version of Chrome the instructor was using as my version had some slight differences.

response.content:
Hi Steven, thank you for the feedback and great review! I appreciate that this was your first course!

Google Chrome is always "evergreen" meaning it will always Auto Update. I was using Chrome Canary which is a few versions ahead of the current version that's out, so that the course will stay relevant more often. I'll see about editing in some video that describes this.

Chrome canary is available here, if you want the latest and greatest https://www.google.com/chrome/browser/canary.html

Rocco
response.content_html:
Hi Steven, thank you for the feedback and great review! I appreciate that this was your first course!

Google Chrome is always "evergreen" meaning it will always Auto Update. I was using Chrome Canary which is a few versions ahead of the current version that's out, so that the course will stay relevant more often. I'll see about editing in some video that describes this.

Chrome canary is available here, if you want the latest and greatest https://www.google.com/chrome/browser/canary.html

Rocco

results.content:
I've been using Chrome Developer Tools for years and already knew of its power. Most of what I learned I did by poking and right clicking and occasionally reading the documentation. I work a lot in SharePoint and was trying to find a way to make WorkSpaces work. Within a few sessions of this course I had figured it out and now have a workflow I can use professionally with consistent results.

Rocco is obviously  very experienced and was born to teach. I hope he keeps on adding and improving the course so I can take it again!

After taking this course, I now know I didn't really know.

results.content: I guess  I am looking for more information. Like tips for changing code into a live window. This is very important, although I do realize that this is early into the instruction and what I am looking for will follow.

response.content:
Hey Cindy, thanks for the review. I go over changing code in a live window later on in the course. 

Just as a reminder, the star rating system is a rating of the entire course and not just the first few lectures. If you take more of the course and find the info that you're looking for, I'd love for you to take another crack at the review.
response.content_html:
Hey Cindy, thanks for the review. I go over changing code in a live window later on in the course.

Just as a reminder, the star rating system is a rating of the entire course and not just the first few lectures. If you take more of the course and find the info that you're looking for, I'd love for you to take another crack at the review.

results.content:
Hey!
Thanks for the course! I'm really glad that I has an opportunity to take it.
Few tips on making it better:
please do not eat during lecturing (even candies :) it makes hard to listen;
I want to see more real world examples. In one of the last lectures where you've discussed memory problems I was glad that you've showed the "you tube frames" problem. Please give more descriptive lecture on that with code an tracking down that problem. It would be great if you'll make such examples for all of the "tools" of dev tools. "Dummy" example is good, real world is much better.
Please structure the course more strict. If you start with short description of the "tools" in dev tools make it shorter and point out for each "tool" which lecture contains expanded description.
May the force be with you!
results.content_html:
Hey!

Please give more descriptive lecture on that with code an tracking down that problem. It would be great if you'll make such examples for all of the "tools" of dev tools. "Dummy" example is good, real world is much better.
Please structure the course more strict. If you start with short description of the "tools" in dev tools make it shorter and point out for each "tool" which lecture contains expanded description.
May the force be with you!

results.content:
This course is a must for beginners, it covers the basics and set a good foundation.
But, it doesn't stop there! it actually helps you to move to the next level.
results.content_html:
This course is a must for beginners, it covers the basics and set a good foundation.

results.content: It's not fair to use the words "to Expert" or "Pro" in the title of this course because it grazes over far too many terms and panel options to equip the viewer with anything comprehensive enough to be close to that. Some areas that could be improved: "Performance tab" - talk about the call tree, and the event log. Talk about the GPU, and the other threads. Talk about the interactions section of the performance panel and how you can troubleshoot this with the feedback on lightbox. Keep the videos up to date. There are some nuggets in here, but its more of a DevTools QuickTips than a Pro.
results.content_html: It's not fair to use the words "to Expert" or "Pro" in the title of this course because it grazes over far too many terms and panel options to equip the viewer with anything comprehensive enough to be close to that. Some areas that could be improved: "Performance tab" - talk about the call tree, and the event log. Talk about the GPU, and the other threads. Talk about the interactions section of the performance panel and how you can troubleshoot this with the feedback on lightbox. Keep the videos up to date. There are some nuggets in here, but its more of a DevTools QuickTips than a Pro.

results.content: Honestly, the course does not go into any reasonable depth about any of the topics, nor provide any examples that make it worth one's time to do the course instead of reading the documentation. Its more like a few minutes of waffling around each tab than a course proper, and those examples used as so lean and contrived as to be not useful. Reading the documentation in as much time as the course takes would give the course participant a much firmer and lucid grasp.
